Article.ArticleTitle: Chronic mitochondrial calcium elevation suppresses leaf senescence.

AbstractText: Mitochondria Ca<sup>2+</sup> overload has long been recognized as a cell death trigger. Unexpectedly, we demonstrated a signaling complex composed of Calmodulin (CaM), Arabidopsis thaliana Bcl-2-associated athanogene 5 (AtBAG5) and Heat-shock cognate 70 protein (Hsc70) within Arabidopsis thaliana mitochondria which transduces mitochondria Ca<sup>2+</sup> elevations to suppress leaf senescence. Gain- and loss-of-function AtBAG5 mutant plants revealed that, mitochondria Ca<sup>2+</sup> elevation significantly increase chlorophyll retention and decrease H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> level in dark-induced leaf senescence assay. Based on our findings, we proposed a molecular mechanism in which chronic mitochondria Ca<sup>2+</sup> elevation reduced ROS levels and thus inhibits leaf senescence.
